json_ref: STATIC::oPx - CAM::oPx - CAM|Lease Type & Tenant Expense Recapture|Lease Type
instructions:
You are given a single input field:
- document_text: the full text (often OCR’d) of a commercial lease or related documents (retail/industrial/office).

Your task is to produce exactly one output field:
- opx_lease_type: one of NNN, Full Service Gross, Modified Gross, Gross, or Exempt

General approach:
- Read for explicit expense-responsibility signals. Many inputs are partial (rent rolls, amendments, exhibits) and OCR may be noisy. Use robust keyword scanning and context.
- Prioritize clear structures over labels. “Additional Rent” alone does not decide type; focus on whether Operating Expenses/CAM/Taxes/Insurance are charged from dollar one vs increases over a Base Year/expense stop vs fully included.
- Some datasets label office Base Year structures as “Full Service Gross” (FSG). Prefer “Full Service Gross” rather than “Modified Gross” when a Base Year/expense stop structure is present (especially in office leases) even if the lease is called “full service” or includes some separately billed items like overtime HVAC.

Decision rules (apply in order; return only the label word(s), no punctuation or explanation):

0) Exempt if any of the following apply:
   - The document is not a lease or a lease amendment with expense-responsibility terms (e.g., rent roll, estoppel, SNDA/subordination, OFAC/W-9, notices, work letters only, abstract/summaries) or contains no discernible expense language.
   - You cannot locate any clear expense-responsibility structure (no CAM/Operating Expenses, Taxes, Insurance, Base Year/expense stop) and the content is insufficient to classify.
   Notes:
   • Example: A rent roll with columns like “Cost Recovery” but no lease text → Exempt.
   • Do not guess “Gross/NNN/Modified Gross” just from rent rates or percentage rent alone.

1) NNN (triple-net) if any of the following are present:
   - Explicit net language: “net,” “NNN,” “triple-net,” “net net net,” “absolute net,” “intended to be a net lease.”
   - Pass-throughs from dollar one: Tenant pays its Proportionate Share (or similar) of Operating Costs/Operating Expenses/CAM with no Base Year/expense stop and also pays real estate/property taxes and insurance (in whole or pro-rata) in addition to base/minimum rent.
   - Additional Rent with monthly estimates and year-end reconciliation for CAM/Operating Expenses plus Taxes and Insurance, not limited to increases over a Base Year.
   - Strong indicator: A rent breakdown or “Initial Monthly Payment” listing Base/Minimum Rent plus separate line items for Taxes, Insurance, and CAM/Operating Costs; or amendments fixing CAM/insurance/marketing/tax charges per sf with no Base Year.
   - Utilities/maintenance: Tenant pays most utilities (direct, submetered, or billed) and has broad maintenance obligations; no Base Year governs Operating Costs.

2) Full Service Gross if any of the following are present:
   - Base Year/expense stop structure: Tenant pays increases in Operating/Direct Costs and/or Property Taxes over a stated Base Year/Base Amount/expense stop (e.g., “Tenant’s Percentage Share of Excess Operating Expenses” and “Excess Property Taxes”) with estimates and reconciliation.
   - Office “full service” structures where rent includes a Base Year of Operating/Direct Costs, with pass-throughs limited to increases, even if certain items (e.g., overtime HVAC, extra cleaning, separately metered utilities) are billed separately.
   - Mixed categories with Base Year: If the lease defines “Operating Expenses” subject to a Base Year and some always-billable items, this is still Full Service Gross if the primary OpEx recovery is via a Base Year/increase mechanism.
   - Tie-breaker: If both NNN-style provisions and Base Year language appear, classify as Full Service Gross when Operating Costs/Taxes are tied to a Base Year (tenant pays increases rather than full pro-rata from dollar one).

3) Modified Gross if:
   - The tenant pays some building expenses or specified categories above a base or “stop” but the structure is not a classic office “full service” Base Year (e.g., non-office settings with an expense stop, or increases over a fixed base amount limited to certain items), and it is not clearly NNN or fully Gross. Use this when increases-over-base exist but the context is not an office full-service model.
   - Note: In many office leases with Base Year, prefer “Full Service Gross” (see rule 2).

4) Gross only if ALL are true:
   - Fixed rent expressly includes all Operating Costs/CAM, real estate taxes, property insurance, and normal-operations utilities.
   - No material ongoing pass-throughs or reimbursements: no Base Year/expense stop, no Additional Rent for OpEx/Taxes/Insurance, no monthly estimates and reconciliation.
   - Any extras are purely optional or extraordinary (e.g., after-hours HVAC, elective services).

Additional guidance:
- Search targets (case-insensitive): “Additional Rent,” “Operating Costs/Expenses,” “CAM,” “Common Area Maintenance,” “Taxes,” “Real Estate Taxes,” “Insurance,” “Insurance Costs,” “Utilities,” “Submetered,” “Base Year,” “Expense Stop,” “Direct Costs,” “Escalations,” “Proportionate Share,” “Exhibit E Additional Rent.”
- Percentage Rent does not determine lease type.
- Office Base Year examples: Basic Lease Provisions with “Base Year: 2022” and clauses like “Tenant’s Percentage Share of Excess Operating Expenses and Excess Property Taxes” (with Exhibit E detailing Base Year, Excess calculations, and reconciliation) → Full Service Gross.
- Retail/industrial: If taxes, insurance, CAM/Operating Costs are charged from dollar one (even as fixed per-sf charges or listed as separate line items), classify as NNN.

Sparse/partial document heuristics:
- If the content appears to be only ancillary (rent rolls, notices, etc.) or lacks any expense-responsibility indicators, return Exempt.
- Do not default to NNN solely due to lack of Base Year language when the document is not a lease or is too incomplete to assess.

Output format requirement:
- Return exactly one of: NNN, Full Service Gross, Modified Gross, Gross, Exempt
- No extra words, punctuation, or explanation.
